titleInfo.title: Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb -- The newly built boys' dormitory, Cottage D

mods.abstract: The boys' dormitory, Cottage D, at the Tennessee School for the Deaf with construction drawing to a close. Windows, doors, and front entry steps have all been added within the course of a month's construction, and no construction equipment is present in this image. Writing on the reverse side of the photograph includes details about furnishings in the dormitory.
mods.accessCondition: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. titleInfo.title: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929

relatedItem.abstract: Tennessee’s School for the Deaf, created by law in 1844, boasts a remarkably long and stable history of educating the state’s students with hearing disabilities. The school has operated since 1845 in Knoxville, closing only for the Civil War and relocating only once (from downtown to an inner suburb). This unit of the Tennessee Virtual Archive features images of this unique institution’s buildings, many of which were designed by noted architect and alumnus Thomas Scott Marr...
